awd_titl_txt: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: Managing Uncertainty in the Design of Safety-Critical Aviation Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this project is to research tools to manage uncertainty in the design and certification process of safety-critical aviation systems. The research focuses on three innovative ideas to support this objective. First, probabilistic techniques will be introduced to specify system-level requirements and bound the performance of dynamical components. These will reduce the design costs associated with complex aviation systems consisting of tightly integrated components produced by many independent engineering organizations. Second, a framework will be created for developing software components that use probabilistic execution to model and manage the risk of software failure. These techniques will make software more robust, lower the cost of validating code changes, and allow software quality to be integrated smoothly into overall system-level analysis. Third, techniques from Extreme Value Theory will be applied to develop adaptive verification and validation procedures. This will enable early introduction of new and advanced aviation systems. These systems will initially have restricted capabilities, but these restrictions will be gradually relaxed as justified by continual logging of data from in-service products. 

The three main research aims will lead to a significant reduction in the costs and time required for fielding new aviation systems. This will enable, for example, the safe and rapid implementation of next generation air traffic control systems that have the potential of tripling airspace capacity with no reduction in safety. The proposed methods are also applicable to other complex systems including smart power grids and automated highways. Integrated into the research is an education plan for developing a highly skilled workforce capable of designing safety critical systems. This plan centers around two main activities: (a) creation of undergraduate labs focusing on safety-critical systems, and (b) integration of safety-critical concepts into a national robotic snowplow competition. These activities will provide inspirational, real-world applications to motivate student learning.

por.por_cntn:
Accomplishments:

1. Our team explored methods to enhance fault-tree analysis to provide more design flexibility for aviation systems.  In particular we investigated how to combine conventional fault analyses with severity levels commonly used by civil aviation authorities (like the FAA).  Additionally, we analyzed automated fault detection, isolation, and recovery (FDIR) systems, assessing methods for representing FDIR on a fault-tree in a manner that is easy to implement with commercial fault-tree software but that still captures the relevant nuances of operating an FDIR-equipped UAS.

2. Our team investigated the role of online bug monitoring in the overall system safety analysis of an important class of CPS: the automated aircraft. We outlined a safety case to describe how software bug monitoring can be coupled with pre-service verification to preserve overall system safety while significantly streamlining existing requirements for aviation software verification. The result is an approach that could allow aerospace software to be deployed much more quickly than is currently possible using conventional verification techniques, such as the industry standard methods detailed in RTCA DO-178.

3. Our team developed a preliminary design for a real-time bug monitor using machine learning concepts. The concept paves the way for online identification of bugs otherwise hidden in operational software. Our team worked with a UAS flight controller, the open source program Ardupilot. We developed and demonstrated a bug-detection algorithm capable of finding real bugs (from the Ardupilot bug logs). We linked our bug monitor to Ardupilot at compile time, so that we could monitor Ardupilot without modifying the source code. We then evaluated the performance for a "snapshot" bug monitor, which operated on data from a single instant in time. Our baseline monitors performed relatively well, achieving AUC values of 85% to 90%. We will pursue even higher-performing adaptations in the future.

 

Impact:

It is expected that the methods developed will allow safety arguments to be based in large part on real-time monitoring, thereby reducing the need for exhaustive a priori verification of complex software and greatly reducing the development time and cost of complex aerospace systems.

This capability is emerging as a major focal issue in UAS development, where software companies find themselves at odds with the traditional aviation industry in that conventional software verification standards are largely impractical for developing low-cost unmanned systems that rely on complex software capabilities. Our research points to an alternative verification approach with the potential to resolve this issue.

 

Note:

This Project Outcome report focuses on the activities of Tufts teammembers. Additional related accomplishments for the overall collaborative project are reported separately by our collaborators at U. Minnesota.
